Chapter 3 Functions and loops 3.1 Why do we need functions? Consider that you need to apply an operation over the elements of a vector. For example, remove all the elements that are maximum over a set of values: One way to do this: x <- c(1, 3, 9, 8, 9, 3, 4, 5, 5, 2, 9, 4, 5, 9) x.max <- max(x) y <- x[x != x.max] y ## [1] 1 3 8 3 4 5 5 2 4 5 If you want to do the same operation on many other vectors, you have to repeat the same 3 lines for each vector. This is not optimal because: - Code is more complex (more lines of the code). - More probability of errors. A function is a piece of code that you can apply over many objects, using a predefined structure. We have been using functions already, however these functions are built-in in R. sort(), which.max(), mean() All of them are functions in r. We can also create our own functions: - A function has always three main elements: - name - parameters (input, and output) - body For our previous example: function.name <- function (input.parameter) { max.value <- max(input.parameter) output <- input.parameter[input.parameter != max.value] return(output) } In this example: - function.name corresponds to the name of the function. - input.parameter corresponds to the input parameter. (could be one or more, separated by comma). - return(output) is the command for returning the output. A more meaningful, and standard definition for our function for the previous example should be: remove.max <- function (input.vector) { max.value <- max(input.vector) output.vector <- input.vector[input.vector != max.value] return(output.vector) } Lets test our function with several inputs. input.vector.1 <- c(1,3,9,8,9,3,4,5,5,2,9,4,5,9) remove.max(input.vector.1) ## [1] 1 3 8 3 4 5 5 2 4 5 input.vector.2 <- c(11,2,11,5,8,5,6,3,5,9,10,8) remove.max(input.vector.2) ## [1] 2 5 8 5 6 3 5 9 10 8 input.vector.3 <- c(1,2,15,6,8,15,1) remove.max(input.vector.3) ## [1] 1 2 6 8 1 Now we want to create a function to remove ONLY!!! the first maximum element of a vector input.vector.1 <- c(1,3,9,8,9,3,4,5,5,2,9,4,5,9) remove.first.max <- function (input.vector) { first.max.input <- which.max(input.vector) output.vector <- input.vector[-first.max.input] return(output.vector) } remove.first.max(input.vector.1) ## [1] 1 3 8 9 3 4 5 5 2 9 4 5 9 Now suppose that we want to have only one function that allows to choose between removing the first maximum element and all the maximum elements. This is allowed by the use of several input parameters, and other complementary bult-in functions: If/else statements input.vector.1 <- c(1,3,9,8,9,3,4,5,5,2,9,4,5,9) remove.max.choose <- function (input.vector, first) { if(first) { max.value <- max(input.vector) output.vector <- input.vector[input.vector != max.value] } else { first.max.input <- which.max(input.vector) output.vector <- input.vector[-first.max.input] } return(output.vector) } remove.max.choose(input.vector.1, TRUE) ## [1] 1 3 8 3 4 5 5 2 4 5 remove.max.choose(input.vector.1, FALSE) ## [1] 1 3 8 9 3 4 5 5 2 9 4 5 9 3.2 FOR LOOP A for loop is a command that allows to iterate over the elements of a vector or iterable element. vector.input.1 <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) for (each.element in vector.input.1) { print(each.element) } ## [1] 1 ## [1] 2 ## [1] 3 ## [1] 4 ## [1] 5 ## [1] 6 3.3 Practice functions 3.3.1 Practice 1: create functions Create a function miles.to.km to convert the distances in miles to distances in kilometers (1 mile ??? 1.609 kilometers).
